edu.calstatela.sawooope.gamestates

Class GameState

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.calstatela.sawooope.gamestates.GameState
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Level, Menu

    public abstract class GameState
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    A GameState is essentially what's being viewed on user's screen.For Example we might want to show a menu. So we draw a menu on the user's screen. On the menu screen there might be a button that says "credits". If the users clicks the credits button, then instead of showing the menu we would now display the credits "page" (more like credits GameState). Of course those two "pages" would look pretty different, but they would both be GameStates since they:
    1. Both handle input from the user's device
    2. Both have something to display on the user's screen
    3. Both (in the case of animations) would need to have their screen's updated and redrawn

    When a GameState is created it automatically runs initialize() on a separate thread. When initialize is done executing, a boolean property "ready" is set to true. Nothing should be draw or updated in a GameState until ready is true.

    Author:
    Benji
